BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 2, 1923

"THAT SHEEPSKIN"
• A college man has the tendency to regard himself as one of a
selected few, as a member of a privileged class. Not many years have
elapsed since this was the' case; when a college education was an
absolute luxury which could be afforded by a relatively small number
of people. In that day a man, upon receiving his degree, became a
member of a small, select group of college graduates, surrounded, on
the outside, by the uneducated mass.
That day is gone. Since the war the popularity of college educations has risen rapidly. At the present time, college graduates in
the West and Middle West are as common as Fords, and in the East
the registration figures at colleges and universities are swelling to
such an extent that steps are being taken to restrict the enrollment.
No longer does a college man find himself a unique and unusual figure
in the business and professional worlds.

FIRST DORMITORY GET-TOGETHER HELD
Dr. Oliver, of the Supreme
Bench, was the speaker at the first
Dormitory get-together held on
Friday night, October 26. He told
the story of a famous murder case.
His descriptions were vivid and
his delivery held his audience. At
the end of his story Dr. Oliver
issued an invitation to everyone
present to attend any of his cases.
The program for the evening
began with a song, "Come Stand
Together." Then "Touchdown"
Abrahams gave a short talk.
Needless to say, "Touchddwn"
left his audience spellbound and
gasping for breath. A musical selection followed, a saxophone solo,
by Livingston, after which Martin gave a violin solo. Both men
were well applauded. Dr. Oliver
was introduced and after him Nelson Young rendered the famous
"Ballad of Yukon Jake."
The evening closed) with the
singing of the University Ode.

There are probably some undergraduates who are still laboring
under the delusion that, after graduation, all one need do is wave a
sheepskin under the eye of some capitalist and one's future is assured.
The undergraduate will find that there are many sheepskins being
Haunted and that the capitalist seldom notices them. A college education is far from a detriment; a man must exhibit more than a
diploma, however, before his services will be in demand.

ROCKS AHEAD
If the curtain could have been rung down on the 1923 football
schedule after last Saturday's game, the season, from a Hopkins standpoint, would have been an unqualified success. But this is only another example of using "if" to bring a moment's satisfaction to the
user. The 1923 football season is not over. Four extremely hard
games remain on the Black and Blue schedule, three of which have a
direct bearing on the State Championship. Coach Van Orman, the
football squad and the undergraduate body have hard work ahead.
Tomorrow the Western Maryland "Green Terrors" will appear
on Homewood Field. Ever since last November the Westminster
student body has been chanting "Beat Hopkins." Their campus is
placarded with signs bearing this slogan and Western Maryland has
a team in keeping with its ambitions. Everything will be needed to
capture tomorrow's game.
It is difficult to realize the closeness of the traditional St. John's
contest, which takes place next Saturday. Then Cornell and, with a
week's interlude, the big game with the powerful University of Maryland eleven.
It is essential that the student body should know that there are
"rocks ahead."

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 2, 1923

"THAT SHEEPSKIN"
• A college man has the tendency to regard himself as one of a
selected few, as a member of a privileged class. Not many years have
elapsed since this was the' case; when a college education was an
absolute luxury which could be afforded by a relatively small number
of people. In that day a man, upon receiving his degree, became a
member of a small, select group of college graduates, surrounded, on
the outside, by the uneducated mass.
That day is gone. Since the war the popularity of college educations has risen rapidly. At the present time, college graduates in
the West and Middle West are as common as Fords, and in the East
the registration figures at colleges and universities are swelling to
such an extent that steps are being taken to restrict the enrollment.
No longer does a college man find himself a unique and unusual figure
in the business and professional worlds.

FIRST DORMITORY GET-TOGETHER HELD
Dr. Oliver, of the Supreme
Bench, was the speaker at the first
Dormitory get-together held on
Friday night, October 26. He told
the story of a famous murder case.
His descriptions were vivid and
his delivery held his audience. At
the end of his story Dr. Oliver
issued an invitation to everyone
present to attend any of his cases.
The program for the evening
began with a song, "Come Stand
Together." Then "Touchdown"
Abrahams gave a short talk.
Needless to say, "Touchddwn"
left his audience spellbound and
gasping for breath. A musical selection followed, a saxophone solo,
by Livingston, after which Martin gave a violin solo. Both men
were well applauded. Dr. Oliver
was introduced and after him Nelson Young rendered the famous
"Ballad of Yukon Jake."
The evening closed) with the
singing of the University Ode.

There are probably some undergraduates who are still laboring
under the delusion that, after graduation, all one need do is wave a
sheepskin under the eye of some capitalist and one's future is assured.
The undergraduate will find that there are many sheepskins being
Haunted and that the capitalist seldom notices them. A college education is far from a detriment; a man must exhibit more than a
diploma, however, before his services will be in demand.

ROCKS AHEAD
If the curtain could have been rung down on the 1923 football
schedule after last Saturday's game, the season, from a Hopkins standpoint, would have been an unqualified success. But this is only another example of using "if" to bring a moment's satisfaction to the
user. The 1923 football season is not over. Four extremely hard
games remain on the Black and Blue schedule, three of which have a
direct bearing on the State Championship. Coach Van Orman, the
football squad and the undergraduate body have hard work ahead.
Tomorrow the Western Maryland "Green Terrors" will appear
on Homewood Field. Ever since last November the Westminster
student body has been chanting "Beat Hopkins." Their campus is
placarded with signs bearing this slogan and Western Maryland has
a team in keeping with its ambitions. Everything will be needed to
capture tomorrow's game.
It is difficult to realize the closeness of the traditional St. John's
contest, which takes place next Saturday. Then Cornell and, with a
week's interlude, the big game with the powerful University of Maryland eleven.
It is essential that the student body should know that there are
"rocks ahead."
